textObjs.text: We'll hear argument next in Number oh one four fifty five, the Franconia Associates versus United States, and the Grass Valley Terrace versus United States.
Justice, and may it please the Court.

you think you have a separate cause of action for the Government's violation of the Constitution, assuming y- that that that you're correct that that's what it's done?

Well, it c- it comes no.
with your argument is that if you have your whole property claim here rests upon the contract.

What's being taken, Justice Souter, is the expected use of the petitioners' properties.
to a certain period of time.
contract for it, you have no right to expect it.

on the part of the pet-

the contract was not clear enough to constitute an enforceable contract with the Government.
I thought the Federal Circuit went on the statute of limitations.
on the basis of the statute...

you presented is whether a breach of contract claim accrues for purposes of section twenty-fi- when Congress enacts a statute alleged to abridge a contractual right to freedom from regulatory cavants [: covenants] upon prepayment of Govern- mortgage loans.
And that's the case we have here.
Didn't the Federal Circuit rely on anticipatory breach?
on anticipatory breach, as I understand it.

We do not either, Your Honor, although the petitioners here have the option of suing assuming suing before the breach, assuming that they had the ability to perform at that time and there's nothing in the record...
the notion that before they went to pay it off, it was an anticipatory breach.
that the reason the statute of limitations doesn't arise, doesn't start to run prior to the time that they paid it off, is because prior to that time, there was no actual breach.
but you take the position that your clients could have filed suit f- soon after the passage of ELIHPA.
take the position let's be clear about...
please that after the enactment of the statute, your c- clients could have filed suit for breach of contract on an anticipatory breach theory?

when when the obligation to perform comes.

about here in performance means w- w- the ability to prepay.

anticipatory breach most people use it not to get damages but to relieve themselves of the obligation of of remaining i- i- in in the status of being able to perform the contract.

the funds until three years from now.

this? Could we agree to this, that so far as the element of an anticipatory breach claim involves the act of the Government, you had that element, and at least to that extent, you could have brought an anticipatory breach claim when the statute was passed? Maybe you didn't have other elements.

for total control then over timing because your client could say, well, we're not ready after five years, we're not ready after seven years, we're not ready after ten years.

deal, and the owners relied on that when they signed up, and they had, you know, a clear expectation that at some point in time they would be able to prepay, opt out, and convert their...

Well, it wasn't just repudi- it's not like a private citizen saying, I don't intend to perform three years from now.
maintain there was no breach at the time the law was passed?
that the statute changed the -- your rights.

The statute did condition them, and that conditioning, or fettering as the Government says, is a repudiation, but like any other situation in the private sector, when you repudiate a right, the breach doesn't occur until the time for performance comes due.
Well, the breach is repudiation if...
to change its mind? Couldn't the Government pass another statute going back to what ze [: the]

seventy-nine they initially conditioned the right, and in nineteen eighty they repealed it, retracted it.
argu- about is whether a statute itself, without any ac- action from the agency, can be a repudiation.
We believe it can be a repudiation, yes, Mr. Chief Justice.
D- Does the repudiation give you the right to the same damages that you would receive for a total breach of the contract?
I think it's usually the case, is it not, that when there's an anticipatory repudiation, it's v- it's very difficult for the the other party to determine what his damages are going to be.
is why he uses the doctrine to get out of the contract rather than to seek damages.

intent to perform and have the...

cash in the bank that would allow you to prepay, and then there's a...

But here, Justice Kennedy, a fifty year option exists.
fifty year options are not subject to valuation? The experts do this all the time.

Well, but even so, even if you could come up with a damage theory to cover this, still it's clear that under the law, the breach would not be deemed to accrue for limitations purposes until the time for performance has arrived and performance failed.

what in the world you are arguing.
if they had the ability to pay, you say.

twenty-three just says that ordinary contract law applies to these this kind of case.

page twenty-seven of the blue brief you say that the law constituted an anticipatory repudiation and petitioners had the option of suing immediately.
In general, yes, that's true, Your Honor.
But the all petitioners commence suit within six years of the date of the actual breach, which is the date that the prepayment requests were denied.
So, what apparently the Government's arguing does it matter if we call this anticipatory repudiation or anticipatory breach? I guess technically...
we should say anticipatory rebudiation? [: repudiation]

Well, here Your Honor, although, yes, we need to construe the statute strictly, we cannot do so in such a manner, however, to narrow the waiver of sovereign immunity that has already occurred under the Tucker Act.

then i- if that's the ca- I me- I mean I really do think that your takings claim, w- w- which is the reason you're going into this thing well, it was just a conditioning of the right it wasn't an elimination of the right it just reduced it you you do all of that to to support your takings claim.
how you can say it was enough for an anticipatory breach, but it wasn't enough for a taking.

not really ready to say there was an anticipatory breach, because in order s- to sustain your takings claim, you don't really want to say there was an anticipatory breach because they didn't really, absolutely break the contract.
both shoulders it seems to me, and and and you're spilling a lot.
in every breach there's also a taking?

what are you adding with this so called takings claim?

Suppose you win on the contract claim.
Well, there are differences between the claims, Your Honor.
full benefit of your contract, which is what would happen if you win on your contract's claim.

to dismiss it too, I suppose.

All we got before us the takings claim.

Well, well would you tell me what you think was taken? Is it the right to prepay that was taken?
If there is no contract right, then no, that was not taken, Your Honor.
their w- is is the is the permitted use of the property under their reasonable invex- investment backed expectation.

at or about the same time.
assume you never made a contract claim.

do you concede or should we take this case on the assumption that there was a contract? Do do we...

the contract included a right of...

contract and and be responsible for damages.
as it does it by legislation, it's okay.
thought that was your point, that that this m- this breach is different because it was done by legislation.
That doesn't mean that that doesn't mean that it's not a breach, but what it means is that the breach is occurring at the time the legislation is...
just curious to get into that a little bit is, I don't understand why the Government is taking the position it does, as well as what the position is.

What what we're what we're asking for is that people who believe that their contractual rights have been injured have been infringed by a statute give the Government reasonably prompt notice, in accordance with the statute of limitations, of their claims.
The the the damages are that petitioners had a loan that they allege gave them a an unfettered option to prepay at any time.

to measure? Y- You you bet your life on that? I mean, the the reason the reason contract law has developed the option of suing for anticipatory breach as just an option is precisely because it is often so difficult to anticipate what your damages will be.
The damages, first of all, can be measured, as I said.
mean, you know, my life expectancy can be measured, but I wouldn't bet a whole lot of money on it.
you can come up with a guess for for for anything.

if it is an option, why should the par- innocent party be penalized by having the sta- statute of limitations start to run then?

to understand the nature of the promise that's that's that's at issue here, I think, and if if I could try to go back to...

to any contract that is ever made.

principle of contract law is that we try to treat the Government and a private contracting party together.
saying the fact that the Government can speak through legislation, whereas a private party cannot, alters that rule.

It may convert one right into a a a right to damages as opposed to a right to performance but the theory of contract is that by repudiation you can't just change the legal rights.
It does it does exactly that.
then exactly the same thing is true in a private contract when there has been an anticipatory...

How does the fact that you cannot...
what it does is show that there's i- there there's a change and an an injury right at the time that the legislation is...

that the laws aren't going to...
and, bingo, there is a breach of contract and you must sue at once.

for the proposition that the y- and an anticipatory breach not accepted by the other party starts the statute of limitations rim- running? I mean, what case?

that has to be there in a contract with the Government...

you could read the statue you...

that's not the law as between private parties.
Yes, given the principles of sovereign immunity and the principle that the statute should be narr- narrowly...
narrow construction notion, or construed strictly notion, applies to deciding whether there's a waiver by the Government of any...

The Court the Court has held several times that statutes of limitations, as conditions on the Government's waiver of its sovereign immunity, should themselves be be narrowly construed and has applied it in in in cases, for instance, involving a situation where a private party claimed that the limitations period didn't run until an administration administrative determination had been made that there wouldn't be that there was a lo- w- was a loss...
in this sense, the Government actually needs less protection than the private party because the Government at least is in a position where it can always pass a statute of limitations...
and if you're if you're if you're concerned about your liability fifty years out or something, I suppose you could pass a statute of limitations.
The Government ha- can do that and has done it here, and the statute of limitations provides that when the action first accrues, there's six years to sue.
Well, but ag- again, I'm I'm back to the problem.

In the in the ordinary situation, if a private party let's let's i- if if I may, let's c- can I pose a hypothetical? of a b- If if a if a private party had promised that you could prepay, that the other party could prepay at any time, and Congress passed a statute that imposed restrictions on prepayment, that statute would be neither an anticipatory repudiation or a breach, but would provide a discharge.
a- about on the merits of the plantiff's...
you're saying that the in Government contracts, there is a promise and there is an issue whether the Government means that promise irrespective of what Congress does in the...
what the Government meant was irrespective of what Congress does, and you're saying no, it meant only if Congress doesn't do to the contrary.
merits, on the merits, yes. But But...
that kind of a contract issue is breached when Congress passes the law to the con-

It could v- enact the the Congress that's close to the first one could say, okay, we'll repeal it.
Mr. Roberts, in the case in which the Government, we'll assume, doesn't change its mind, your argument in in response to Justice Breyer's question seems to boil down to something like this.
Well, W- When when there's a present when there's a breach, the the general principle is the statute of limitations starts to run at the time of the breach.
It doesn't wait to run until...

your argument, as I understand it, is that because of the Government's peculiar power to pass legislation, the Government should not be in the position of the usual contract breaker who may be subject to an anticipatory breach claim or an actual breach claim later.
se- sus- there's a a very strong interest in permitting the Government to in permitting Congress to decide it wants to wrap up the costs of improvident Federal...

wi- The th- the Government doesn't know who's going to sue, for one.
the Government may get off a little cheaper if it puts the burden on the...
i- there's a dispute here as to whether the contract made this promise or not, and the Government doesn't doesn't know how that dispute's going to be resolved.

Well, when they breach a contract and it's a breach, the the statute of limits does start to run and the rule is that even if the damages can't be fully ascertained, that that the statute of limitations run.
it's so hard to look at this as an actual breach if we take it on the assumption there was a contractual right of prepayment on demand by the borrower.

there was a request to prepay.
all petitioners have made requests to prepay.
some of the petitioners in this case.
to prepay and it's been refused.

and in not having to wait for fifty years to know...
